quoteFirst: The Canadian attack went well, but very stiff opposition was encountered in Marquion, so that the 56th Division attack from the Blue line had to be postponed from 2.48 p.m. to
quoteLast: Excellent work was done by the 512th and 513th Field Companies, R.E. (56th Division), in bridging the Canal at Marquion.
title: The War History of the 4th Battalion, the London Regiment (Royal Fusiliers), 1914-1919
author: Grimwade, F. Clive

quoteLast: the Kensingtons commenced their attack and progressed without difficulty as far as their first objective, the east and west road through Sauchy-Cauchy. North of this, however, they were met with stubborn resistance from machine-guns in Mill Copse and the marshes east of the Canal.
title: The War History of the 4th Battalion, the London Regiment (Royal Fusiliers), 1914-1919
author: Grimwade, F. Clive

quoteFirst: But the village of Marquion was on the east of the canal, and on the Arras-Cambrai road, and at 11.45 a.m. the village was still holding out, which made it impossible for the 169th Brigade to keep to the time-table and be in position for attack by 2.48 p.m. It was therefore decided to postpone the attack until
title: The 56th Division (1st London Territorial Division)
author: Dudley Ward, C. H. (Charles Humble), 1879-1945; Horne, Henry, 1861-1929 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: After we had gone about half way round, 'Now,' said Mr. Gurney, 'I will show you her speed.' He did, and we completed seven turns round the outside of the road by
quoteLast: . If, therefore, as I was there assured, two and a half turns measured one mile, we went 2.8 miles in ten minutes; that is, at the rate of 16.
title: The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction. Volume 14, No. 391, September 26, 1829
author: Various

quoteFirst: To cook supper by and iron Abie's pyjamas. Here was democracy. Here is progress--here is the substance of words--UMMMMM: that is to say meat or linen or belly ache.--Three A.M. To be exact
title: The Great American Novel
author: Williams, William Carlos, 1883-1963
